properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A frontal system bearing subtropical moisture will move across the Columbia region beginning tonight. Snow will fall throughout tonight and the day on Sunday but will intensify Sunday afternoon and continue into Sunday night.. Total snowfall accumulation for Sunday and Sunday night may reach 40 cm. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-21T16:02:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-21T00:03:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0372926270.2021
Area: Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this morning. Heavy flurries off of Lake Huron are occurring this morning. Additional local snowfall accumulations of up to 5 cm and reduced visibility are likely this morning. Locally heavy flurries may persist into the afternoon for southern Huron and Perth Counties. Motorists are advised to exercise caution as snow will make travel difficult in some areas. Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-21T02:54:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-20T13:27:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4172317311.2021
Area: Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County, Listowel - Milverton - Northern Perth County, Goderich - Bluewater - Southern Huron County, Stratford - Mitchell - Southern Perth County, Mount Forest - Arthur - Northern Wellington County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect through early this afternoon. Heavy flurries off of Lake Huron continue. Snowfall rates of a few centimetres per hour and significantly reduced visibilities have been observed with these flurries. Additional snowfall accumulations may reach 5 cm locally by the time the snow tapers to flurries this afternoon. Motorists are advised to exercise caution as snow will make travel difficult in some areas. Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extremely cold wind chills near minus 55 continue this morning. Wind chill values are expected to be in the minus 45 to minus 50 range by Saturday evening. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-21T06:03:38-00:00

Area: Resolute

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow changing to heavy rain with the potential for heavy snow at the summit for Sunday night. A frontal system laden with subtropical moisture will move across southern B.C. beginning tonight and lasting until Sunday night bringing a messy mix of rain on top of snow on Sunday and the possibility of heavy wet snow at the summit Sunday night. The initial warm front will slowly raise snow levels tonight with snow still falling on the upper elevations of the Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt and Highway 3 via Allison Pass. By Sunday morning, the warm airmass will be over southern B.C. with snow levels near or slightly above the Coquihalla Summit and Allison Pass. Rain will fall over most of the highway with wet snow or rain mixed with snow near at summit. As the cold front approaches Sunday night, precipitation rates will intensify and thus there is potential for snow levels to drop just below the summit or pass levels, resulting in heavy accumulating snow up to 15 cm. Motorists are advised to be aware of changing weather and road conditions due to fluctuating snow levels and precipitation intensity during this period. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-21T16:02:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-21T00:03:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1374232005.2021
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. A warm front moving across the Whitehorse and Carcross area will produce 10 centimetres of snow by midday on Sunday before ending Sunday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm continues. A frontal system is spreading snow the Williston region and the Pine Pass. Total snowfall accumulation of 10 to 15 cm will fall in the Williston region before the snow changes to rain Sunday morning. The precipitation will remain as snow over the Pine Pass until late Sunday afternoon with total snowfall accumulations of 20 to 30 cm expected. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions are forecast to end early this evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. A frontal system bearing subtropical moisture has made landfall on the north and central coast. Rain will become heavy at times tonight and then gradually ease on Sunday for the north coast and Sunday night for the central coast. Rainfall amounts of 100 to 150 mm are expected by Sunday evening. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-21T16:13:22-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong westerly winds will develop overnight in conjunction with a disturbance moving in from British Columbia. Gusts in excess of 100 km/h can be expected later tonight and through the day on Sunday. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rain begins tonight as a frontal system bearing subtropical moisture pushes onto the B.C. coast. 50 to 80 mm of rain will fall. Stewart and Kitimat will see upwards of 50 mm of rain tonight. Bella Coola will see rain tonight but the heaviest rain will arrive on Sunday and continue Sunday night. Up to 80 mm will fall by Sunday night. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. There was less warming today than expected and rain has changed to snow in Stewart. With temperatures hovering right near zero, the heavier precipitation expected tonight should bring enough cooling to keep the majority of the precipitation as snow. The snow may become mixed with rain at times Sunday morning as precipitation rates ease and temperatures rise slightly. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-21T16:21:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-21T00:22:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0723550438.2021
Area: North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentrations of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality. High concentrations of pollutants are expected to continue until early Sunday morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canadas website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministre de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montral, visit the Rseau de surveillance de la qualit de lair de la Ville de Montrals website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Qubec, visit the Ministre de la Sant et des Services sociauxs website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction rgionale de sant publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-lle-de-Montral at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-02-21T16:59:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministre de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministre de la Sant et des Services sociaux, the Direction rgionale de sant publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-lle-de-Montral, the City of Montral, 2021-02-21T02:21:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4017762677.2021
Area: La Sarre area, Amos area, Lebel-sur-Quvillon area, Senneterre area, Rouyn area, Malartic area, Val d'Or - Louvicourt area

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Heavy snow and blowing snow today and tonight for White Pass to Fraser Camp as a frontal system pushes onshore across the South Klondike Highway. A total of 20 to 30 cm will fall near White Pass by Sunday morning. Strong southwest winds will today will give reduced visibility in blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
